text: Hey everybody. Uh, nice to see you.

overviewing

Um I have some other friends from our
company here. We can chat afterwards
also, but um hopefully it's helpful.
It's a bit of a different look. So, uh,
Southern Partner Studios and where I
work in our business, we work in live

main focus is that the majority of our
work is for live. Um, usually they are
very very large live shows. Uh that's
not to brag or say they're amazing or
whatever, but just from a sense of
context, we are talking very large
screens, lots of people, and um big sort
of impact. Uh the thing about those big

horrific rainstorms, uh power outages,
uh prepping computers in hotel rooms. Um
my friend Grant here super sick at

there at the bottom trying to render out

settle or just to give you an idea of

like the scale and the type of work we

about life is that it's different every

asked to do lots of different types of
things. So, here's a little quick

Um, yeah. So, lots of fun stuff. Um,
again, uh, the biggest thing I think
about when I see stuff like that is that
the variety is quite intense. One day
we're doing claymation and handdrawn
animation, the next day we're doing a
live film shoot in the desert, and then
the next day we're doing like a flame
simulation and ranging from screens the
size of this to something that is 26,000
pixels wide. and usually from 4 to 6
weeks of time production usually. So, um
quality might be a little bit different
than a uh major motion picture or
something like that. Um but there's
definitely a lot of variety which is
quite fun. So, SPS is actually based in
Montreal. It was started uh 10 years
ago. Um and it was started by a group of
people who are uh photographers,
artists, directors, VJs, um all sorts of
people in the live space. And we grew
over the last 10 years to open an LA
office. That's where I came in around
2015, opening office out there. And it's
grown. It was, you know, four people
trying to make pretty pictures on screen
whenever we could. And now it's turned
into a about a 50 person company making
visuals all over the world and lots of
concurrent shows. So it's definitely
grown over time. Um, but the fun thing
about it is that it's grown in terms of
the type of work and the type of
technology as well. So that's one of the
reasons why I wanted to dig into it
today is that real time has always been
part of what we do um working in
especially in music. So starting in Max
MSP and Touch Designer and Quartz
Composer and like all these different
fun tools, it's all grown over time. Um
I think one of the main focuses too,
like I said earlier, is that our main
projects are for the in-person
experience, which is a little bit
different than some folks who are doing
stuff for screens or for camera or
something like that. So there's some
other things to consider as part of that
process. But again, uh, one thing that's
very fortunate about the live show world
or kind of odd is that if you want to
work on a show that has a giant screen,
um, it's quite expensive to do that from
a production standpoint. So you very
conveniently end up working with some
fairly large artists because they're the
ones who can afford the massive screens,
but um, it makes it very interesting. It
makes it very creative, which is really
fun. Um, so yeah, over the years we've
been able to work with a lot of really
interesting people and again like I was
saying, some of it uh ranges from a
liveaction shoot with Taylor Swift to a
extended reality shoot with Camila Cabo
down in the corner. So it really really
changes um quite a bit which is fun. But
it it goes back into roots like I said
of like a lot of people who at our
company were VJs and artists and
photographers. And this is a we did a
Coachella show, a Swedish House Mafia
about 15 years ago. So it's it's really
been a nice long journey there. Um lots
and lots of shows. Uh but I think again
the style of it is really what's
interesting too. Like we don't get to or
choose to work in one particular way.
Sometimes it's really busy like this or
you know um Cardi B wants to be standing
on a hand for whatever reason at a show
and then the next day you're doing
something that's more serious. Um, for
me personally, my background, um, I kind
of bopped around like a lot of people in
this industry. I, uh, worked at a place
called the New World Symphony here in
Florida, actually down in Miami, and it
was kind of a dream gig, uh, right out
of school. Um, they just opened this
amazing facility that is a Frank Gary
building. If you're ever down there, go
check it out. It has 360 projection on
the inside during symphony concerts. And
it was an amazing experience where I got
to go and first day on the job had to
replace projector lamps and then the
next day I had to make content for the
show and then edit and it was just a lot
of a lot of stuff with a small group of
people which is really fun. After that I
went and worked with another company
called Lighttor in Ohio um in
Cincinnati, Ohio doing shoe commercials
for Echo. I don't know I just kind of
stumbled into that. Uh and then that
evolved into combining a lot of those
things with commercial and projection
and we started doing more projection
mapping. So that was a project with uh
McLaren back in the day. Um but that
eventually kind of led into a bunch of
technology and a bunch of different
things and it led into my understanding
of Unreal Engine which for a lot of
people here might know more than me or
have had a different experience, but
when I knew Unreal, I thought of Unreal
Tournament and like video games and and
Gears of War and stuff like that. And I
remember always watching it and seeing
it grow, but it was always something
kind of in the distance. like you're
aware of it, but I was paying attention
to more other production based tools.
Um, but you saw it grow and change until
um the logo got less aggressive over the
years as well. So, by the time it got to
Unreal 4, we started to kind of pay
attention to it with the big release of
it being more accessible and free. Um,
more on that for a second. I need to
kind of backstep why it's interesting,
too, cuz something that happens in
shows, um, there's unfortunately tropes
that are kind of done all the time. So,
we are always making clouds. I know it's
really silly, but like all the time we
have to make clouds or smoke or fog or
something like that. So, my first sort
of real moment, aha moment with Unreal
was the week that UE4 came out, they
released this uh hang glider demo. I
don't if you guys remember seeing that
and you played it, but there was a
moment where I was in rehearsal. We're
trying to render out some uh clouds and
some haze and it just was being
miserable and we opened up this demo and
it was like can we just like do that?
Can we just render that out because it
just would work. So it's kind of a weird
tangential thing but it was just one of
those crossover moments when you realize
that technology that is being built for
games and for other purposes if we could
record this out and put it in another
medium it'd be really helpful. So we
ended up using a bunch of that on this
Selena Gomez show in whatever year it
was. It was a really interesting little
tidbit for Unreal for me. But I think I
want to focus more um not just on
Unreal, but it's about real time in
general. Something that's been really
helpful over the last 10 years, I think,
is that the conversation about real time
has been less of a abstract thing. Uh
we're all used to it a lot more now on
our phones, on our computers, in our
everyday life. You're just kind of aware
that you can hit a button and something
will happen automatically. And that's
been really, really exciting. Um, I'm
part of another organization called
Framework. Uh, I helped start this, uh,
I don't know, right before COVID. Uh,
definitely check it out if you're
interested. There's a QR code for the

tangental, but it's a side plug for it
because I think if you're in this talk,
you're probably interested in it cuz
it's a community for people who work in
real time visuals, graphics, technical
stuff, design stuff, anything like that.
And um it can go way more in depth than
what I'm able to do about real time. But
something that I really appreciated

uh show another talk at a talk but I

things for convenience, but it has all
these other flexibility and important
options. The sort of classic example is
the tree up in the top corner from a
virtual production shoot a couple years
ago, but moving a tree and blocking the
sun and changing the position, doing
that in real time is not just convenient
because you don't have to render it and
wait. You can also just get feedback on
set and the director can say, "Hey, what
if that tree was there?" And then the
talent can see on screen and they can
look back and know that there's a tree
there. There's all these sort of like,
you know, um, advantages that come from
that. And it becomes an emotional
feedback loop. Um, I think the other
thing about it that's fun, too, is that,

something that will come up in this

And does it really need to be is all
kind of interesting stuff.
Um a little bit of a again going down
the history of Silent Partners. Uh we
had a little uh detour in 2020 as a lot
of people did um not only during COVID
but also because of this big bump that
happened in XR and virtual production
and stuff like that. So um we uh started
a sister company called XR Studios. I
was across that. A lot of you here know
me from that as well. Um, but it was
something that we started to really
focus in on virtual production, AR, uh,
camera track based real-time
environments. And I think it's an
interesting thing to touch on because it
had to be real time. That was the most
amazing thing about the big virtual
production push is that it had a
requirement to be real-time so the
cameras could track and change
positions, but the benefit of that is
that now everyone started working in a
real-time space, which was really great.
It really pushed things forward. So, we
did this project that um got a decent
amount of attention, which was this
performance with Katy Perry on American
Idol. It was not made in Unreal, sorry.
Um but it was still using real-time
workflows and tracking. And it was a
nice way to show that again, like I was
saying earlier, it doesn't have to be um
Mandalorian style or like a rock and
tree sort of realistic environment. It
can be playful, it can be fun, and it
can still benefit from real-time
technology. Um that grew over time and
we created the studio in LA. Um, it was
a crazy 5-year adventure with two
massive stages and we were able to do a
bunch of different types of projects,
but most of them were focused in music
and live. We weren't focused as much on
film and TV, but uh, music projects with
Katy Perry and Billy Isish, um, Leon
Bridges and lots of other people. Um,
and a lot of it was television focused.
So, we were able to do the VMAs in 2020
and um, MTV Movie Awards and a couple
other things. But what became really
interesting about all of this was
real-time design and content design for
immersive environments for camera was
really influenced by our work in the
physical space. So a lot of what we were
doing was building these large physical
sorry virtual representations of
physical sets in the space. So hosting
environments, areas with screens, um
virtual screens, but all of that that
you see was done on LED stages. So, St
Partners was able to take our experience
in the real world, bring it to the
virtual world, and we came out the other
side with some interesting experience.
Um, esports became a really big part of
that and has continued to um as well as
AR graphics for broadcasts. Um, again,
more AR stuff for esports. There's some
really fun work with Valerant over the
years that again was kind of perfect for
that sort of world and style and
environment, which is great. Um, but
there was some cinematic stuff as well
too. you know, we definitely spent some
time trying to create real world
environments or Mars, I guess, for this.
Um, and again, leveraging different
real-time tools between Unreal, Notch,
Unity, all sorts of things during that
time. Um, and finally, the last part of
that is uh the corporate world is
obviously a big play in using all that
stuff. So that was a big uh a big uh

more stylized sort of corporate

realistic presentations as well using
Unreal. Um I think virtual production is
a whole other side topic that's not
really this talk but it's just
interesting to touch on because a lot of
the stuff that we learned in that space
and that a lot of people learned in that
space has now come back the other side
into the live entertainment world and
it's really interesting. So working on
really convincing backgrounds and
shadows and stuff like that um really
high quality rendering has also
transferred over into the real world
space which is great. So today in 2025
um the where we stand with all this sort
of stuff and the million acronyms that
exist for it. Um we're still doing a lot
of work in the virtual production and AR
space. We don't run a stage anymore
which is to be honest kind of nice. Um
but uh there's lots of stuff happening
in that space. So, some more recent
things from there. We did this project
recently with Katy Perry in Australia
using augmented reality and it's a good
example of, you know, she had to do a
daytime performance in Australia and
it's quite hard to make daytime shows
exciting. Um, it's sunlight, you can't
use screens, you can't use lighting that
much. So, in order to elevate it a bit,
um, she decided to, you know, lean on
some more fantastical elements. And so
this is a project done with Unreal
Engine inside of a Vizrt wrapper with
Stype camera tracking. Um some nice
examples of like reflections and shadows
and stuff like that which is kind of fun
but also it's just like giant shiny
metallic butterflies as well. So the the
pressure is pretty low. Um so that's
something we're still doing keeping
pretty active with. Another thing we're
keeping active with is still virtual
production work using mostly as VAD
artists and creating environments. So,
we just did a shoot recently with our
friends at Mario Studio over in London,
and it was just a reminder of like,
you know, reflections are obviously this
big exciting thing for car shoots for
virtual production, but being in an
unreal environment was what was really
exciting about the shoot. This tunnel
that you see in that shot is an Unreal
scene. and being able to change the
width of it, size of it, uh, animating
the lights down at on the moment, and
just live actively change things made
for a really fun experience for the
director and the DP and just made for a
really good shoot. And, uh, again with
that real-time feedback, it's silly cuz
it's just a car in front of a screen,
but them seeing when stuff is flashing
at them or not allows them to react to
it and turn to it. And again, that
little bit of feedback is what's really
helpful.
So, that was a bunch of detours into the
VP world. Uh going back into the more
live world, wanted to talk a little bit
about uh some of the live shows that we
are doing nowadays or have done recently
that do use Unreal Engine. Um again,
it's just a tool and there's a lot of
tools involved, but it's helpful to kind

think something to talk about with live
shows, like I was saying at the
beginning a bit, is that things have a
lot of factors in that space that are a
bit bizarre. you know, the timeline is
short, but the resolution is really
large. The budget is generally a little
bit smaller. Um, the team style is a bit
different. There's a lot of expanding
and contracting in that space, just like
a lot of industries where lots of
freelancers, contractors, friends, uh,
other studios. So, all those factors
like are part of the reason why
something might be using Unreal or
another tool or something else. There's
all these different things that you can
pull on. So even though you could do
something one way, you end up choosing
to do it another way because of all
these other extraneous factors.
Something that's really interesting in
live shows too is that there's the
touring aspect of it or like the sort of
actual production aspect of it that's
quite tricky. So even if I want to run
something in Unreal, I need to consider
should it be running live? What kind of
machines are going to be running it
live? And how does someone set that up
every day for the next 9 months in, you
know, 120 different cities? So, how is
it going to be calibrated in the
morning? What are the troubleshooting
things? There's a lot of factors in
there to consider um when and why to use

I think for Unreal, I think it's an
interesting thing that we are building
and growing. I think a lot of our teams
are using it more and more. I think

even from something as small as being

our sort of like last thought from the
SPS side of things is just to play. Like
I was saying, take stuff that was built
uh for something else, break it, turn it
on its head. And part of that play also
is with real time, like we were saying
for Leah Hane and the other projects is
even though it's real time design
doesn't mean it needs to be realtime
rendered. So using it to play and
experiment and see what you want and
what you need and what works great for
the artist is helpful, but it doesn't
actually have to be rendered if you
don't want it to be. Um, on the other
side, if you're doing a music
